citations.narrative:
The licensee did not follow the Program of Veterinary Care related to the administration of heartworm preventative
medication. The Program of Veterinary Care, signed and dated 3/18/2022, called for the monthly administration of
heartworm prevention to all dogs over 8 weeks of age. However, the licensee stated that he did not administer heartworm
prevention to the dogs over 8 weeks of age in the month of September.
Failure to follow the Program of Veterinary Care can lead to harm to the animals from the inappropriate administration of
medication or the development of illnesses the Program of Veterinary Care is meant to prevent.
The licensee must follow the Program of Veterinary Care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, and signed by
the attending veterinarian.
To be corrected by close of business on 11/8/2024.

The written Program of Veterinary Care, signed and dated 3/18/2022, did not contain preventive care procedures for
ensuring healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth.
A preventive care program that includes regular examination of the dogs to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats,
properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes and teeth is essential to keeping dogs in good health and preventing
disease and/or injury.
The licensee must ensure that the written Program of Veterinary Care for dogs includes a preventive care program for
ensuring healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth.
To be corrected by close of business on 12/30/2024.

Records of administration of anti-parasitic medications for intestinal parasites were not maintained for adult dogs sold and
held by the licensee. The written Program of Veterinary Care, signed and dated 3/18/2022, required that pregnant
females receive a 10-day course of fenbendazole starting at 53 days of gestation. The licensee stated that he has been
administering the fenbendazole to his pregnant females as described in the Program of Veterinary Care; however, he has
not been documenting this activity.
Medical records are essential for APHIS inspectors to evaluate the quality of medical care provided by the facility and
ensure the animals are protected from disease, injury, and illness.
The licensee must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for APHIS inspection. These
records must include routine husbandry procedures (such as vaccinations, preventive medical procedures, and
treatments) performed an all animals.
To be corrected by the close of business on 11/15/2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
n

narrative:
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee did not follow the Program of Veterinary Care related to the administration of heartworm preventative 
medication. The Program of Veterinary Care, signed and dated 3/18/2022, called for the monthly administration of 
heartworm prevention to all dogs over 8 weeks of age. However, the licensee stated that he did not administer heartworm 
prevention to the dogs over 8 weeks of age in the month of September.  
 
Failure to follow the Program of Veterinary Care can lead to harm to the animals from the inappropriate administration of 
medication or the development of illnesses the Program of Veterinary Care is meant to prevent. 
 
The licensee must follow the Program of Veterinary Care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, and signed by 
the attending veterinarian.  
 
To be corrected by close of business on 11/8/2024. 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The written Program of Veterinary Care, signed and dated 3/18/2022, did not contain preventive care procedures for 
ensuring healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. 
 
A preventive care program that includes regular examination of the dogs to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, 
properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes and teeth is essential to keeping dogs in good health and preventing 
disease and/or injury.  
 
The licensee must ensure that the written Program of Veterinary Care for dogs includes a preventive care program for 
ensuring healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on 12/30/2024.

3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Records of administration of anti-parasitic medications for intestinal parasites were not maintained for adult dogs sold and 
held by the licensee. The written Program of Veterinary Care, signed and dated 3/18/2022, required that pregnant 
females receive a 10-day course of fenbendazole starting at 53 days of gestation. The licensee stated that he has been 
administering the fenbendazole to his pregnant females as described in the Program of Veterinary Care; however, he has 
not been documenting this activity. 
 
Medical records are essential for APHIS inspectors to evaluate the quality of medical care provided by the facility and 
ensure the animals are protected from disease, injury, and illness. 
 
The licensee must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for APHIS inspection. These 
records must include routine husbandry procedures (such as vaccinations, preventive medical procedures, and 
treatments) performed an all animals.  
 
To be corrected by the close of business on 11/15/2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
